facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 871 of 1964 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated January 16, 17, 1961 of the Gujarat High Court in Special Civil Application No. 233 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 871 of 1964. Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 16, 17, 1961 of the Gujarat High Court in Special Civil Application No. 233 of 1960.

facts.text: The appellants Company was registered under the Indian Companies Act, 1913.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants Company registered under the Indian Companies Act, 1913 was assessed in the assessment years 1948-49 to 1953-54 in respect of the profits earned in its business, and was allowed rebate under the appropriate provisions companytained in the Schedules to the relevant Finance Acts on the undistributed profits of the previous years.

facts.text: On December 31, 1956 at an annual general meeting of the shareholders the Company declared an aggregate sum of Rs. 2,15,232/- as dividend for the year ending December 31, 1956.

facts.text: A special resolution was passed for voluntary winding up of the Company with effect from October 1, 1957, and for appointing a liquidator to wind up the affairs of the Company.

Thereafter a special resolution was passed for voluntary winding up of the Company with effect from October 1, 1957, and for appointing a liquidator to wind up the affairs of the Company.

The Income-tax Officer, Special Investigation Circle-B, Ahmedabad in exercise of the power under s. 35 10  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, passed an order withdrawing the rebate, granted in respect of each of the six assessment years 1948- 49 to 1953-54 and demanded payment of tax on the amount of the rebate.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer, Special Investigation Circle-B, Ahmedabad passed an order withdrawing the rebate granted in respect of each of the six assessment years 1948-49 to 1953-54 under s. 35(10) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, Special Investigation Circle-B, Ahmedabad in exercise of the power under s. 35 10  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, passed an order withdrawing the rebate, granted in respect of each of the six assessment years 1948- 49 to 1953-54 and demanded payment of tax on the amount of the rebate.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer demanded payment of tax on the amount of the rebate.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, Special Investigation Circle-B, Ahmedabad in exercise of the power under s. 35 10  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, passed an order withdrawing the rebate, granted in respect of each of the six assessment years 1948- 49 to 1953-54 and demanded payment of tax on the amount of the rebate. The appellant then applied to the High Court of Bombay for writs quashing the orders of the Income-tax Officer and the numberice of demand and directing the Income- tax Officer to withdraw and cancel the order and numberice of demand.

facts.text: The appellant applied to the High Court of Bombay for writs quashing the orders of the Income-tax Officer and the notice of demand.

The petition was dismissed by the High Court.

facts.text: The High Court dismissed the petition.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was dismissed by the High Court. With certificate granted by the High Court, this appeal has been preferred.

facts.text: With certificate granted by the High Court, this appeal has been preferred.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was dismissed by the High Court. With certificate granted by the High Court, this appeal has been preferred. Two questions are raised for determination in this appeal Whether S. 35 10  authorises the Income-tax Officer to bring to tax rebate granted in assessment years companymencing prior to April 1, 1956 and  2  whether distribution by the liquidator of accumulated profits in the previous years companyld be regarded as declaration of dividend within the meaning of S. 35 10  so as to attract the applicability of the provisions enabling withdrawal of rebate and demand for tax.

facts.text: Two questions are raised for determination in this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: With certificate granted by the High Court, this appeal has been preferred. Two questions are raised for determination in this appeal Whether S. 35 10  authorises the Income-tax Officer to bring to tax rebate granted in assessment years companymencing prior to April 1, 1956 and  2  whether distribution by the liquidator of accumulated profits in the previous years companyld be regarded as declaration of dividend within the meaning of S. 35 10  so as to attract the applicability of the provisions enabling withdrawal of rebate and demand for tax.

facts.text: In Ahmedabad Manufacturing and Calico Printing Co. Ltd. v. S. G. Mehta, declaration of dividend by the Company was made on April 20, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: In Ahmedabad Manufacturing and Calico Printing Co.s case 1  declaration of dividend by the Com- pany was made on April 20, 1953. The financial year in which the amount on which rebate of income-tax was allowed was availed of by the Company for declaring dividends was 1953-54, and within four years from the end of that year an order calling upon the Company to show cause why action should number be taken under s. 35 10  to recall the proportionate part of the rebate was issued.

facts.text: Sub-section (10) of s. 35 was inserted in the Income-tax Act by s. 19 of the Finance Act, 196, with effect from April 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  10  of s. 35 was inserted in the Income-tax Act by s. 19 of the Finance Act, 196, with effect from April 1, 1956. It provides Where, in any of the assessments for the years beginning on the 1st day of April of the years 1948 to 1955 inclusive, a rebate of income-tax was allowed to a companypany on a part of its total income under clause  i  of the proviso to Paragraph B of Part I of the relevant Schedules to the Finance Acts specifying the rates of tax for the relevant year, and subsequently the amount on which the rebate of income-tax was allowed as aforesaid is availed of by the companypany, wholly or partly, for declaring dividends in any year, the amount or that part of the amount availed of as aforesaid, as the case may be, shall, by reason of the rebate of incometax allowed to the companypany and to the extent to which it has number actually been subjected to an additional income-tax in accordance with the provisions of clause  ii  of the proviso to Paragraph B of Part I of the Schedules to the Finance Acts above referred to,. be deemed to have been made the subject of incorrect relief under this Act, and the Income-tax Officer shall recompute the tax payable by the companypany by reducing the rebate originally allowed, as if the recomputation is a rectification of a mistake apparent from the record within the meaning of this section and the provisions of sub-section  1  shall apply accordingly, the period of four years specified therein being reckoned from the end of the financial year in which the amount on which rebate of income-tax was allowed as aforesaid was availed of by the companypany wholly or partly for declaring dividends.

facts.text: The Company resolved to be voluntarily wound up under the Companies Act 1 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On the passing of a special resolution by the Company that it be wound up voluntarily under the Companies Act 1 of 1956, the Company does number stand dissolved.

facts.text: The Company was registered under the Indian Companies Act, 1913.

anchor.surface_text: The Company in the present case was registered under the Indian Companies Act, 1913. The Articles of Association of the Company are number before us, but the Articles relating to distribution of dividend being under S. 17 2  of the Companies Act, 1913, obligatory, Arts. 95, 96 and 97 in Table A of Act 7 of 1913 applied.

facts.text: Counsel for the Company urged that in the Ahmedabad Manufacturing case power to withdraw rebate granted before April 1, 1952 was not exercisable.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Company urged that in the Ahmedabad Manufacturing and Calico Printing Co.s case it was held that power to withdraw rebate granted in the year before April 1, 1952 was number exercisable by the Incometax Officer under S. 35 10  and companysistently with that view withdrawal of rebate granted in the years ending on and before March 31, 1952 was unauthorised.

arguments.claim: In the Ahmedabad Manufacturing case, it was held that power to withdraw rebate granted before April 1, 1952 was not exercisable under S. 35(10), so withdrawal of rebate for years ending on or before March 31, 1952 is unauthorised.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Company urged that in the Ahmedabad Manufacturing and Calico Printing Co.s case it was held that power to withdraw rebate granted in the year before April 1, 1952 was number exercisable by the Incometax Officer under S. 35 10  and companysistently with that view withdrawal of rebate granted in the years ending on and before March 31, 1952 was unauthorised.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: cturing and Calico Printing Co.s case it was held that power to withdraw rebate granted in the year before April 1, 1952 was number exercisable by the

arguments.court_reasoning: Ahmedabad case held power exercisable within 4 years from end of financial year when availed for dividend, not limited to rebates granted after April 1, 1956; argument imports limitation contrary to plain words.

arguments.claim: S. 35(10) applies even to rebates where dividend declared before April 1, 1956, as concluded by Ahmedabad Manufacturing case.

anchor.surface_text: The first question is companycluded by a recent judgment of this Court in Ahmedabad Manufacturing and Calico Printing Co. Ltd. v. S. G. Mehta, Income-tax Officer and Another 1 . In that case this Court held that s. 35 10  applied even though dividend was declared before April 1, 1956.

arguments.claim: Power under S. 35(10) cannot be exercised because distribution of accumulated profits by the liquidator is not distribution by the Company.

anchor.surface_text: It is urged by companynsel for the Company that power under sub- s.  10  of s. 35 cannot be exercised because distribution of accumulated profits by the liquidator is number distribution by the Company.

arguments.court_reasoning: Liquidator in members' voluntary winding up is agent of Company; Company retains corporate existence, property vests in Company; liquidator exercises directors' powers per Companies Act ss.487,491,512.

arguments.claim: Company retains corporate existence and powers during voluntary winding up until dissolution; liquidator acts as agent distributing on behalf of Company.

anchor.surface_text: The argument is wholly without substance. On the passing of a special resolution by the Company that it be wound up voluntarily under the Companies Act 1 of 1956, the Company does number stand dissolved. That is so expressly provided by s. 487, of the Companies Act.

arguments.claim: On commencement of winding up, distinction between capital and accumulated profits disappears; distributions by liquidator are of capital regardless of source, not dividends.

anchor.surface_text: It is then urged that on the companymencement of winding up, distinction between the capital and accumulated profits of the Company disappears, and what remains in the hands of the liquidator are the assets of the Company, and distributions made by the liquidator are distributions of capital... In support of this companytention, reliance was placed upon Inland Revenue Commissioners v. George Burrell.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the liquidation companymenced. By the Finance Act, 1955, the proviso to cl.  c  was omitted thereby accumulated profits whether capitalized or number

arguments.court_reasoning: Burrell rule superseded by statutory definition in s.2(6A)(c); legislative amendments from 1939, 1955, 1956 include liquidation distributions from accumulated profits as dividends.

arguments.claim: Distributions by liquidator from accumulated profits are dividends under s.2(6A)(c); Burrell rule no longer applies due to statutory definition superseding it.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Companies Act, 1956, accumulated profits... companye into the hands of the liquidator as assets... But the rule in Burrells cave 1 since the amendment of the definition of dividend in s. 2 6A  by the Finance Act, 1956, numberlonger applies...

arguments.court_reasoning: No warrant for distinction; distribution by working company is dividend under s.2(6A)(a), by liquidator under (c).

arguments.claim: Distributions from accumulated profits are dividends whether by working company under s.2(6A)(a) or in liquidation under s.2(6A)(c).

anchor.surface_text: For this distinction again there is numberwarrant. Distribution of accumulated profits by a Company number subject to winding up is distribution of dividend by virtue of S. 2 6A   a , and distribution of accumulated profits in the companyrse of liquidation is dividend by virtue of s. 2 6A  c .

arguments.claim: Even if accumulated profits distributed by liquidator are dividends, power under s.35(10) cannot be exercised because liquidator is not declaring dividends per Companies Act requirements.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that assuming that accumulated profits of a Company distributed by the liquidator may be regarded as dividends, power under s. 35 10  cannot be exercised in respect of those profits, because the liquidator is number in distributing the profits declaring dividends.

arguments.court_reasoning: Assumption that dividends only declared per formalities without substance; interim dividends distributable by directors/liquidator justified by profits per Companies Act 1913 Arts.95-97, s.172; s.205 requires out of profits.

arguments.claim: Liquidator's distributions of accumulated profits are interim dividends under Companies Act provisions; no special machinery or conditions for interim dividends, so qualify as declaration of dividend for s.35(10).
S.35(10) and amended s.2(6A)(c) form a single scheme to treat distribution of accumulated profits (capitalized or not) as dividends and withdraw rebate if availed for such.

anchor.surface_text: Amendment to cl.  c  in s. 2 6A  was made and s. 35 10  was inserted in the Income-tax Act simultaneously by the Finance Act, 1956. It would be reasonable to regard the provisions of s. 35 10  and amended cl.  c  of sub-s.  6A  of s. 2 as part of a single scheme to declare distribution of accumulated profits...

arguments.claim: Expression 'dividend' in s.35(10) has meaning per s.2(6A), nothing repugnant suggesting otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the definition of dividend in s. 2 6A  c  win apply only if there is numberhing repugnant in the subject or companytext in which the expression dividend occurs in s. 35 10 , but there is numberhing in s. 35 10  which suggests that the expression dividend was to have a meaning different from the meaning assigned to it by the interpretation clause.

holdings.text: s. 35(10) applied even though dividend was declared before April 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In that case this Court held that s. 35 10  applied even though dividend was declared before April 1, 1956. Counsel for the Company urged that in the Ahmedabad Manufacturing and Calico Printing Co.s case it was held that power to withdraw rebate

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows binding precedent from Ahmedabad Manufacturing case; rejects petitioner's misinterpretation distinguishing pre-1952 rebates; limitation period reckoned from year of availing for dividend, not grant date.

holdings.text: Power to withdraw rebate was ... exercisable within four years from the end of the financial year in which the amount of rebate was availed of [and] it was not held that the power was exercisable in respect of rebate granted only in respect of four years before April, 1956. The argument ... must therefore be rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Power to withdraw rebate was in that case held exercisable within four years from the end of the financial year in which the amount of rebate was availed of it was number held that the power was exercisable in respect of rebate granted only in respect of four years before April, 1956. The argument raised by companynsel importing a limitation companytrary to the plain words of the statute must therefore be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets precedent correctly; plain words of statute do not import limitation to post-1956 grants; 4-year period from availing year.

holdings.text: distribution of accumulated profits by the liquidator is [a] distribution by the Company [as] [t]he liquidator appointed in a members winding up is merely an agent of the Company.

anchor.surface_text: The liquidator appointed in a members winding up is merely an agent of the Company to administer the property of the Company for purposes prescribed by the statute. In distributing the assets including accumulated profits the liquidator acts merely as an agent or administrator for and on behalf of the Company.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Companies Act provisions (ss.487,491,512): company retains existence and property until dissolution; directors' powers vest in liquidator as agent.

holdings.text: the rule in Burrells case ... no longer applies, when the liability to assessment of income-tax in respect of amounts distributed out of accumulated profits by a liquidator in a winding up falls to be determined.

anchor.surface_text: But the rule in Burrells cave 1 since the amendment of the definition of dividend in s. 2 6A  by the Finance Act, 1956, numberlonger applies, when the liability to assessment of income-tax in respect of amounts distributed out of accumulated profits by a liquidator in a winding up falls to be determined.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory inclusive definition in s.2(6A)(c) from 1939, amended 1955/1956, supersedes common law Burrell rule; includes liquidation distributions attributable to accumulated profits.

holdings.text: Distribution of accumulated profits by a Company not subject to winding up is distribution of dividend by virtue of S. 2(6A)(a), and distribution of accumulated profits in the course of liquidation is dividend by virtue of s. 2(6A)(c).

anchor.surface_text: Distribution of accumulated profits by a Company number subject to winding up is distribution of dividend by virtue of S. 2 6A   a , and distribution of accumulated profits in the companyrse of liquidation is dividend by virtue of s. 2 6A  c .

holdings.reasoning_summary: No warrant for distinction; definition applies unless repugnant, none in s.35(10); harmonious construction with amendments.

holdings.text: The liquidator ... did from time to time distribute accumulated profits, and within the meaning of s. 2(6A)(c) read with the provisions of the Companies Act, they were distribution of interim dividends.

anchor.surface_text: The liquidator of the appellant companypany did from time to time distribute accumulated profits, and within the meaning of s. 2 6A  c  read with the provisions of the Companies Act, they were distribution of interim dividends.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interim dividends distributable by directors/liquidator justified by profits per Table A Arts.95-97, s.172 Companies Act 1913; no special formalities required beyond out of profits (s.205).

holdings.text: Distribution of accumulated profits by the liquidator together with the income-tax refund certificate in the course of voluntary winding up may therefore, for the purpose of s. 2(6A)(c), be regarded as declaration of dividend.

anchor.surface_text: Distribution of accumulated profits by the liquidator together with the income-tax refund certificate in the companyrse of voluntary winding up may therefore, for the purpose of s. 2 6A  c , be regarded as declaration of dividend.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No artificial meaning to 'declaring dividends'; s.35(10) and s.2(6A)(c) single scheme; applies definition; Companies Act permits interim distributions as dividends.

anchor.surface_text: In support of this companytention, reliance was placed upon Inland Revenue Commissioners v. George Burrell 1 . The Court in that case held that on the winding up of a limited companypany the undivided profits of the past year and the year in which winding up occurred were only assets of the companypany

precedents.case_name: Inland Revenue Commissioners v. George Burrell
precedents.cited_proposition: on winding up of company, undistributed profits are assets not income, no supertax on distribution
precedents.cited_holding: on the winding up of a limited companypany the undivided profits of the past year and the year in which winding up occurred were only assets of the companypany and on distribution amongst the shareholders supertax was number payable on the undivided profits as income

anchor.surface_text: But the rule in Burrells cave 1 since the amendment of the definition of dividend in s. 2 6A by the Finance Act, 1956, numberlonger applies, when the liability to assessment of income-tax in respect of amounts distributed out of accumulated profits by a liquidator in a winding up falls to be determined.

precedents.case_name: Inland Revenue Commissioners v. George Burrell
precedents.cited_proposition: rule that distributions in winding up are not income

anchor.surface_text: This was clearly an attempt to supersede the rule in Burrells case 1 . It was pointed out by this Court in Dhandhania Kedia Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax 2 that s. 2 6A c was enacted to remove the anomaly which was created by the judgment in Burrells case 1

precedents.case_name: Inland Revenue Commissioners v. George Burrell
precedents.cited_proposition: created anomaly regarding distribution of accumulated profits in liquidation

precedents.citation: Dhandhania Kedia Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax 2

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out by this Court in Dhandhania Kedia Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax 2 that s. 2 6A c was enacted to remove the anomaly which was created by the judgment in Burrells case 1 , and to assimilate the distribution of accumulated profits by a liquidator to a similar distribution by a Company which is working.

precedents.case_name: Dhandhania Kedia Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: s. 2(6A)(c) enacted to remove anomaly of Burrell's case and treat liquidator distributions as by working company
precedents.cited_holding: s. 2 6A c was enacted to remove the anomaly which was created by the judgment in Burrells case 1 , and to assimilate the distribution of accumulated profits by a liquidator to a similar distribution by a Company which is working

anchor.surface_text: that s. 2 6A c was enacted to remove the anomaly which was created by the judgment in Burrells case 1 , and to assimilate the distribution of accumulated profits by a liquidator to a similar distribution by a Company which is working. But the language of the clause and the proviso thereto included only those accumulated profits which had number been capitalized

precedents.cited_proposition: judgment creating anomaly in treatment of liquidator distributions

The liquidator appointed in a members winding up is merely an agent of the Company to administer the property of the Company for purposes prescribed by the statute. In distributing the assets including accumulated profits the liquidator acts merely as an agent or administrator for and on behalf of the Company.
